recordings.loc: Portal, Arizona
recordings.rmk: juvenile calling while foraging on limbs of an introduced elm tree; rare here; this individual otherwise photographed and observed for a couple of weeks; regular calls while clinging to a limb, burrier calls three times in flight (after 0:36, 0:59, and 1:02) (audible wingbeats at these times, too); very soft little kip note after 1:01 and 1:02 are by the sapsucker; in juvenile plumage, which they retain into winter, but a migrant to here, no longer on the breeding grounds;

recordings.file-name: XC137670-Yellow-bellied Sapsucker drum, Jim Lake, Alaska.mp3
recordings.rmk: First borough record. First heard drumming, then used playback to bring it closer for documentation with photos and recording. Used Sennheiser ME 67 and Olympus LS11. Intervals of 25 seconds and 40 seconds edited out, as well as one drumming bout marred by iPhone interference sounds. Deamplified with Audacity, as original was over the sound limit.

recordings.rmk: Unmodified recording. White birch, other deciduous trees, mixed with a few spruce and balsam fir; dense growth and the birches were growing almost to the water's edge. Fog was lifting, sky was overcast with no blue showing. Temp. in low 60s. No boats seen or heard and no vehicles parked in the boat launch. Female Wood Duck with ducklings on the lake.

recordings.loc: Breitung Township (near  Quinnesec), Dickinson County, Michigan
recordings.rmk: Territorial dispute among several adult Yellow-bellied Sapsuckers (6 seen) in a woods near Little Fumee Lake that seemed to be favored by several woodpecker species perhaps because there were several good snags with resonant properties. They were flying back and forth, acting very aggressively towards each other, as well as making several different kinds of calls.  Birds were always at least five meters from the ground and were very active.  Unfiltered recording, trimming only at the beginning and end; three Northern Flicker vocalizations between 50 sec. and 1:50, Blue Jay at end of recording. Camera clicks.

recordings.loc: Luyben Mainline Access Road, Liard Highway, British Columbia
recordings.rmk:
2nd recording at this site;
The first and fifth drums sound different, and could be sapsucker or American Three-toed Woodpecker, but the calls and the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th drums are Yellow-bellied Sapsucker (seen in that direction);

recordings.loc: Westborough, Worcester, Massachusetts
recordings.rmk: Quite surprised to see an unidentified sapsucker fly by when I was checking out passerines feeding on snow-free hillside.  Eventually the bird started calling, and I I was able to record a few notes.  I eventually tracked the bird down to confirm it was a female Yellow-bellied Sapsucker, a pretty good bird here in the winter.
